questions.question: What is this course about?
questions.answer: This course teaches high school students how to use Linux, the operating system that powers most of the internet, smartphones, supercomputers, and even the Mars Ingenuity helicopter. You'll learn command-line skills, shell scripting, file management, networking, and how to work with Raspberry Pi hardware.

questions.question: Who is this course for?
questions.answer: This course is designed for high school students (grades 10-12) who are curious about how computers really work. No prior Linux experience is required. You should have basic typing skills and access to a Linux terminal.

questions.question: What do I need to get started?
questions.answer: You need access to a Linux terminal through Mac Terminal, Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), Chromebook developer mode, or a Raspberry Pi. Strong typing skills including copy/paste are essential.

questions.question: Do I need a Raspberry Pi?
questions.answer: A Raspberry Pi is highly recommended but not strictly required. Many exercises work on any Linux terminal. However, chapters on GPIO, hardware projects, and IoT specifically require a Raspberry Pi.

questions.question: What's the difference between Linux and UNIX?
questions.answer: UNIX was created at Bell Labs in 1969 by Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie. Linux is a UNIX-like operating system created by Linus Torvalds in 1991 that's free and open source. Linux follows UNIX philosophy and is compatible with UNIX commands.

questions.question: What is an operating system?
questions.answer: An operating system (OS) is software that manages computer hardware and provides services for programs. It handles memory allocation, file storage, process scheduling, and hardware communication. Linux, Windows, and macOS are all operating systems.

questions.question: What is a shell?
questions.answer: A shell is a command-line interpreter that processes your typed commands and communicates with the operating system. Bash and Zsh are the most popular shells. The shell is your direct connection to the power of Linux.

questions.question: What is the terminal?
questions.answer: The terminal (or terminal emulator) is the application that provides a text-based interface to the shell. It's where you type commands and see output. The terminal is just the window—the shell is what interprets your commands.

questions.question: What is a file system?
questions.answer: The file system is how Linux organizes and stores files on disk. Unlike Windows (C:, D:), Linux uses a single tree structure starting from the root /. Everything—files, devices, even running processes—appears as part of this hierarchy.

questions.question: What is the root directory?
questions.answer: The root directory / is the top of the Linux file system hierarchy. All other directories branch from it. Don't confuse this with the root user (superuser) or the /root directory (root user's home).

questions.question: What is my home directory?
questions.answer: Your home directory is your personal space at /home/username. It contains your files, configurations, and settings. The shortcut ~ (tilde) represents your home directory, so cd ~ takes you home from anywhere.

questions.question: What are file permissions?
questions.answer: File permissions control who can read, write, or execute files. Every file has three permission sets: owner, group, and others. Each set can have read (r), write (w), and execute (x) permissions.

questions.question: What is chmod?
questions.answer: The chmod (change mode) command modifies file permissions. You can use symbolic mode (chmod u+x file) or numeric mode (chmod 755 file). Understanding chmod is essential for running scripts and securing files.

questions.question: What is sudo?
questions.answer: Sudo (superuser do) lets you run commands with administrator privileges. Instead of logging in as root (dangerous!), you prefix commands with sudo to temporarily gain elevated access. For example, sudo apt update updates packages with admin rights.

questions.question: What is a process?
questions.answer: A process is a running instance of a program. Every command you run creates a process with a unique Process ID (PID). Linux can run thousands of processes simultaneously. Use ps to list processes and kill to stop them.

questions.question: What is piping?
questions.answer: Piping uses the | symbol to send output from one command as input to another. For example, ls -l | grep '.txt' lists files and filters for .txt files. Pipes embody the UNIX philosophy of small tools working together.

questions.question: What is an environment variable?
questions.answer: Environment variables are named values available to programs. Common examples include PATH (where to find commands), HOME (your home directory), and USER (your username). View them with echo $VARIABLE or printenv.

questions.question: What is PATH?
questions.answer: PATH is an environment variable listing directories where the shell looks for executable commands. When you type python, the shell searches each PATH directory until it finds the program. Incorrect PATH settings cause 'command not found' errors.

questions.question: What does ls -la show?
questions.answer: The command ls -la lists all files (including hidden ones starting with .) in long format showing permissions, owner, group, size, date, and filename. The -l flag means long format; -a means all files.

questions.question: What is the difference between rm and rmdir?
questions.answer: rm removes files (rm file.txt) or directories with contents (rm -r folder/). rmdir only removes empty directories. Use rm -r carefully—it recursively deletes everything inside!

questions.question: What is grep and how do I use it?
questions.answer: grep (Global Regular Expression Print) searches for patterns in files or output. Basic usage: grep 'pattern' file.txt. Common options: -i (ignore case), -r (recursive), -n (show line numbers).

questions.question: What are regular expressions?
questions.answer: Regular expressions (regex) are patterns for matching text. Special characters like . (any character), * (zero or more), and ^ (start of line) create powerful search patterns.

questions.question: What is the difference between apt and brew?
questions.answer: apt (Advanced Package Tool) is the package manager for Debian/Ubuntu Linux. brew (Homebrew) is a popular package manager for macOS. Both install software from repositories using similar commands.

questions.question: What is SSH?
questions.answer: SSH (Secure Shell) provides encrypted remote access to other computers. Use ssh user@hostname to connect. SSH is essential for managing remote servers, Raspberry Pis on your network, and cloud instances.

questions.question: What is a shell script?
questions.answer: A shell script is a text file containing commands that execute sequentially. Start with a shebang (#!/bin/bash), make it executable (chmod +x script.sh), then run it (./script.sh). Scripts automate repetitive tasks.

questions.question: What is cron?
questions.answer: Cron is a time-based job scheduler that runs commands automatically at specified intervals. Edit your crontab with crontab -e. Example: 0 2 * * * /home/user/backup.sh runs a backup daily at 2 AM.

questions.question: What is systemd?
questions.answer: Systemd is the init system and service manager for modern Linux. It starts the system, manages services, and handles system state. Commands like systemctl start nginx and systemctl enable nginx control services.

questions.question: What is the difference between nano and vim?
questions.answer: Nano is a simple, beginner-friendly text editor with on-screen shortcut hints. Vim is a powerful, modal editor with a steeper learning curve but greater efficiency for experienced users.

questions.question: What is GPIO?
questions.answer: GPIO (General Purpose Input/Output) refers to the 40-pin header on Raspberry Pi boards. These pins can be programmed to read sensors (input) or control LEDs, motors, and other devices (output).

questions.question: What is Docker?
questions.answer: Docker is a containerization platform that packages applications with their dependencies into isolated containers. Unlike virtual machines, containers share the host OS kernel, making them lightweight and fast.

questions.question: What are tar, gzip, and zip?
questions.answer: tar archives multiple files into one (doesn't compress by default). gzip compresses single files (.gz extension). tar.gz combines archiving and compression. zip is Windows-compatible compression format.

questions.question: Why do I get 'permission denied'?
questions.answer: This error occurs when you lack the necessary permissions. Solutions: Check permissions with ls -l, use sudo for system files, use chmod to add execute permission for scripts, or ensure you own the file with chown.

questions.question: Why do I get 'command not found'?
questions.answer: This error means the command isn't in your PATH. Fixes: Check spelling (Linux is case-sensitive!), install the package (apt install package), use the full path, or check PATH with echo $PATH.

questions.question: How do I stop a running command?
questions.answer: Ctrl+C interrupts and stops the command. Ctrl+Z suspends the command (use fg to resume, bg for background). Ctrl+D sends end-of-file (exits shells and programs waiting for input).

questions.question: Why won't my script run?
questions.answer: Common issues: No execute permission (fix with chmod +x script.sh), wrong shebang (first line should be #!/bin/bash), wrong path (use ./script.sh), or Windows line endings (fix with dos2unix).

questions.question: How do I find a file?
questions.answer: Multiple approaches: find for powerful search by name, size, time (find /home -name '*.txt'). locate for fast database search. which to find commands. whereis to find binaries, sources, manuals.

questions.question: How do I see what's using disk space?
questions.answer: df -h shows disk usage for all mounted filesystems. du -sh * shows size of items in current directory. du -h --max-depth=1 / shows size of top-level directories. ncdu is an interactive analyzer.

questions.question: Why is my process using 100% CPU?
questions.answer: Use top or htop to identify the process, then wait for it to finish if legitimate, use nice or renice to lower priority, or kill with kill PID or kill -9 PID for force kill.

questions.question: How do I safely shutdown my Raspberry Pi?
questions.answer: Never just unplug the power! Use sudo shutdown now for immediate shutdown, sudo shutdown -h +5 for shutdown in 5 minutes, or sudo reboot to restart. Improper shutdown can corrupt the SD card.

questions.question: Should I always use sudo?
questions.answer: No! Only use sudo when necessary for system administration. Running everything as sudo is dangerous—you could accidentally delete system files. Follow the principle of least privilege: use only the permissions you need.

questions.question: How should I organize my files?
questions.answer: Follow the XDG Base Directory standard: ~/Documents for documents, ~/Downloads for downloads, ~/Projects for coding projects, ~/.config for application configurations. Create meaningful subdirectories and use clear naming conventions.

questions.question: What's the best way to backup my files?
questions.answer: Multiple approaches: rsync for efficient incremental backups, tar for compressed archives, Git for version control of code projects, automated scripts with cron. Follow the 3-2-1 rule: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 offsite.

questions.question: How do I write clean shell scripts?
questions.answer: Best practices: Start with #!/bin/bash shebang, add comments explaining what the script does, use meaningful variable names, quote variables ('$var'), check command success with exit codes, use set -e to exit on errors.

questions.question: How do I secure my Linux system?
questions.answer: Essential security practices: Keep system updated with apt update && apt upgrade, use strong passwords, disable root login over SSH, use SSH keys instead of passwords, configure firewall (ufw or iptables), review running services.

questions.question: When should I use absolute vs relative paths?
questions.answer: Absolute paths (/home/user/file): Use in scripts, cron jobs, and configurations where reliability is essential. Relative paths (./file or ../folder/file): Use for convenience when working interactively. Scripts should generally use absolute paths.

questions.question: How do I keep my system clean?
questions.answer: Regular maintenance: apt autoremove removes unused packages, apt clean clears package cache, journalctl --vacuum-size=100M limits log size, remove old files from ~/Downloads, use du to find space hogs.

questions.question: What is the difference between containers and virtual machines?
questions.answer: Virtual machines run a complete operating system with its own kernel on virtualized hardware—heavy but fully isolated. Containers share the host kernel and package only the application with dependencies—lightweight and fast. Docker uses containers; VirtualBox uses VMs.

questions.question: What is Kubernetes?
questions.answer: Kubernetes (K8s) is a container orchestration platform that automates deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. It's the industry standard for running containers in production at scale.

questions.question: What is Infrastructure as Code?
questions.answer: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) means managing servers, networks, and cloud resources through configuration files rather than manual setup. Tools like Terraform and Ansible let you version control your infrastructure and recreate it reliably.

questions.question: What is DevOps?
questions.answer: DevOps combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) practices to shorten the development lifecycle and deliver software continuously. DevOps engineers use Linux, containers, CI/CD pipelines, and automation tools.

questions.question: What is the difference between C and Rust?
questions.answer: C is the original systems programming language that UNIX and Linux are written in—fast but prone to memory errors. Rust is a modern alternative offering memory safety without garbage collection. The Linux kernel is gradually adopting Rust for new code.

questions.question: How does Linux run on Mars?
questions.answer: NASA's Ingenuity helicopter runs Linux! It uses a radiation-hardened processor running a real-time Linux variant. The Mars 2020 mission chose Linux for its reliability, open-source nature, and extensive testing. Space agencies worldwide trust Linux for critical missions.

questions.question: What Linux certifications should I get?
questions.answer: Popular certifications: Entry level includes CompTIA Linux+ and LFCA. Intermediate includes LFCS and RHCSA. Advanced includes LFCE and RHCE. Start with hands-on experience, then consider certifications to validate your skills.

questions.question: What can I build with a Raspberry Pi?
questions.answer: Endless possibilities: Web server with Nginx or Apache, media center with Plex or Jellyfin, network-wide ad blocker with Pi-hole, retro gaming with RetroPie, VPN server with WireGuard, IoT hub, Minecraft server, and much more.

questions.question: How long will this course take?
questions.answer: This is a 15-week semester-long course. Each chapter is designed to be completed in approximately one week, with hands-on exercises and practice projects. The pace is flexible—some students move faster, while others take more time.

questions.question: What makes this course different from other Linux tutorials?
questions.answer: Most Linux books are dry, technical manuals designed for IT professionals. This course uses humor, real-world examples, interactive MicroSims, and hands-on Raspberry Pi projects to make learning Linux actually fun.

questions.question: Can I use this course on a Mac?
questions.answer: Yes! macOS is based on BSD UNIX, so most commands work identically. Open Terminal and you're ready to go. A few Linux-specific features (like apt) differ, but the core skills transfer perfectly.

questions.question: What if I break something?
questions.answer: That's the beauty of learning on a Raspberry Pi—if you break it, just reflash the SD card and start over! On other systems, most commands can be undone, and we teach safety practices throughout. Make backups and don't be afraid to experiment.

questions.question: How do I get help when I'm stuck?
questions.answer: Linux has excellent built-in help: man command shows the manual page, command --help shows quick usage, apropos keyword searches for related commands. Online communities like Stack Overflow and r/linux are also helpful.

questions.question: What is the difference between bash and zsh?
questions.answer: Both bash and zsh are shells that interpret your commands. Bash is the traditional default on most Linux systems. Zsh (the default on modern macOS) offers enhanced features like better tab completion, spelling correction, and themes.

questions.question: What is stdin, stdout, and stderr?
questions.answer: These are the three standard streams in Linux: stdin (0) is standard input (keyboard), stdout (1) is standard output (terminal), stderr (2) is standard error (terminal). You can redirect these using <, >, and 2>.

questions.question: How do I delete a file that starts with a dash?
questions.answer: Files starting with - are interpreted as options. Solutions: Use ./ prefix (rm ./-file) or use -- to signal end of options (rm -- -file). Example: rm -- -myfile.txt deletes a file named -myfile.txt.

questions.question: Who created this course?
questions.answer: This course was developed by Dan McCreary using Claude Code and the intelligent textbook methodology. It combines decades of Linux experience with AI-assisted content generation to create an engaging, comprehensive learning resource.

questions.question: Can I contribute to this course?
questions.answer: Yes! This course is open source. You can report issues on GitHub, suggest improvements, contribute examples or exercises, and help translate content. Community contributions are welcome and encouraged.

questions.question: Where can I find additional resources?
questions.answer: Resources include the Glossary of Terms with 540 Linux terms defined, the Learning Graph for visual concept maps, online communities like r/linux and Stack Overflow, and official documentation through man pages and project wikis.
